posts.name: yair
posts.cooked: i am tring to make a wood bolt and i have trouble with the bend it has at the top of the bolt

posts.name: Nick Aarestad
posts.cooked: Hi! Can you post a picture of the type of bolt you are trying to replicate? That will help anyone who wants to help you.

posts.name: yair
posts.cooked: it lets me put out only 1 image

posts.name: B
posts.cooked: Assuming by “the bend” you mean the bolt head. I would use a wooden dowel the same diameter as the bolt head and then just put it on a lathe and just remove the desired length of excess down to the thread diameter you want.

posts.name: yair
posts.cooked: sorry but what do you mean by lathe?

posts.name: Liam Fay
posts.cooked: Are you asking for help making it in real life or in CAD?

posts.name: yair
posts.cooked: I am trying to do it in onshape as a CAD

posts.name: Liam Fay
posts.cooked:
Gotcha!

By the bend, do you mean the domed face featured on bolts such as carriage bolts?

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
Here is some inspiration to use. The wood versions (if made in real life) are not identical to the metal (or plastic) counterparts.

Thread pitch (angle) is different,  parts fit together looser, etc.

This Baby & Toddler Toys item by KidsTimberToys has 8 favorites from Etsy shoppers. Ships from The Netherlands. Listed on Mar 10, 2024

Price: EUR 22.50

link_counts.title: Wooden Bolt and Nuts,wooden Threading Bolt Toy, Wooden Threading Toys, Montessori Kids Toys, Kids Learning Toys, Wooden Kids Toys. - Etsy

posts.name: B
posts.cooked: A lathe is a machine used typically on round objects. It spins the material you want to cut down, and then you can make round patterns/ designs using one, or you can cut down the diameter of the material very precisely. Since you asked that, going off the assumption you do not have a lathe you could use a trill and set up a lathe esque setup, or you could hand file down a dowel, but that will be hard because bolts usually need to be pretty accurately sized. Also using if you are using a wooden bolt, it very well my crack and break whilst you are putting it in if it gets torqued too much.

posts.name: yair
posts.cooked: no its not an outside bend but a bend from the head to the body of the bolt like in wood bolts

posts.name: B
posts.cooked: Oh sorry, I misunderstood I thought you were trying to make one irl.

posts.name: B
posts.cooked: OHH, that is called a countersunk screw/bolt, mk cad may have one, I don’t have onshape open right now but I would check there.

posts.name: Liam Fay
posts.cooked: Oh!! Gotcha. Rather than extruding a circle to make the head of the screw, you can create a right triangle and revolve it around. I’m not at home so I can’t draw it out, but this may help: Revolve

posts.name: B
posts.cooked:
Here is a very inaccurate example, but still gets the point across. The images are out of order, but the lower one is the sketch I made, and you can just change the rectangle sizes to be the radius of the screw you want, and then just make a triangle and a smaller rectangle and then revolve it around the lower line connecting everything. Good luck!
